ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SALE OF HDB SHOPS BY PUBLIC TENDER
(Details)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development (a) if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board whether the details for the sale of the 100 shops by public tender are ready; and (b) whether the Government will reconsider the plight of those shopkeepers affected by resettlement and give them a cash compensation or a choice to rent shops, indicating the number of shopkeepers affected as at 28th July, 1987.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, the details for the sale of some 100 new shops are being finalized by the HDB. The Board will make a press announcement on this as soon as the details are ready. The shops will be sold by public tender, on 99-year leases. Besides selling these new shops on

Column: 60

tender, HDB will let out another 600 shops over the next 12 months, by tender on fixed-term tenancies of one to three years.

    Under the current resettlement policy, effective from 28th July 1987, resettlement shopkeepers are paid a cash grant. Those who wish to rent HDB shops will have to tender for them. To help the resettlement shopkeepers in their tenders, a preferential margin of 10% will be given to resettlement shopkeepers who are sole occupiers of affected premises. In the case of resettlement shopkeepers who share premises, a preferential margin of 5% is given. This policy has not changed.

    There were 2,075 shopkeepers affected by clearance as at 28th July 1987 when the resettlement policy was revised.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I know why the Hon. Minister cannot reconsider - I say "reconsider" - the position with a view to giving those shopkeepers affected by resettlement the option to rent the shops, as was the case in the past?

Column: 61



     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, the answer is very simple. We just do not have enough shops. With your permission, Sir, may I distribute this table which sets out the availability of shops at the present moment? [Copies of table distributed to hon. Members.]

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as the Member for Punggol can note from this schedule that is being distributed, as I mentioned in my answer, there were 2,075 resettlement shops as at 28th July 1987. There are several categories. Some were already offered shops but they did not accept; there are 600 of them. Others had Notices to Quit served on them but no offer has been made yet, and there are still others who have been already identified and they know that they are going to be cleared but no Notices to Quit have been served. So there were 2,075 resettlement cases as at 28th July. Since we have already cleared most of the squatter areas, we expect over the next few years to have another 50 to 100 new resettlement cases as from 1988 onwards.

    As against this potential demand for resettlement shops, you can see that the supply is only 546 at the present moment, with another 150 new shops which HDB will complete every year for the next few years.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, even if half the resettlement cases want shops and the other half are prepared to settle for cash, there are still just not enough shops to offer all resettlement cases. Moreover, Sir, I think it is bad policy and not in the interest of the public and the residents in HDB estates to allow all shops to be taken up by resettlement cases . We want a mix of resettlement shopkeepers as well as new businesses. So we just do not have enough shops. I have looked at this matter very sympathetically. I have asked the officials to try and examine whether we can accommodate those on whom Notices to Quit have been served and who want shops, and whether we can in fact offer them shops.

    Sir, the facts are these. Of the 546 shops that are now available, not all of them when tendered out will be able to survive. Quite a few of them are shops which have become vacant many times because

Column: 62

businesses have not been able to make a go at that particular site. We really have just too many shops catering for too few people in the HDB areas. This is the reason why HDB has decided that from next year, they will build only 150 shops a year. So taking all these figures into account, it is not possible with all the goodwill in the world to try and accommodate the request of the resettlement shopkeepers.

    I must also mention that the revised resettlement policy allows a cash grant for shops in temporary premises. The shops in temporary premises did not have this option of taking cash under the previous policy. So at least they have a cash grant now.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Jalan Kayu): Sir, may I ask the Minister, in view of what he has said, whether the policy could be modified to (a) give a higher preferential margin in the bidding, say, from the present 10% to 50%; and (b) to provide for enhanced compensation as in the case of farmers where their structures and improvements are currently compensated at higher levels than those of non-farmers. In this respect, Sir, may I also ask the Minister to have the Resettlement Committee look into other proposed modifications.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there are no plans to give a higher preferential margin. In fact, I looked at the terms of tenders by resettlement shopkeepers, and I find that even giving them a 20% margin will not make any difference. A 50% margin, I think, is just unthinkable.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we are dealing with property on behalf of the public and there is a responsibility on the part of the Government that we get the best for the taxpayers.

     Mr Tang See Chim (Chu Chu Kang): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister consider allowing only those resettled shopkeepers to tender for the shops? Would the Minister give the reason why it is not in the public interest to allow only shopkeepers affected by resettlement to tender? These people are in the business, and so they should know better than fresh entrants into the retail trade.

Column: 63



     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the second part of his question answers the first part. If they know better, they should be able to compete with fresh entrants into the business.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, whilst I am not entirely in disagreement with the Hon. Minister's answer, nevertheless could I ask him to ascertain from the HDB whether they could increase the number of shops available? The figure given here is 150 which, I think, is hardly sufficient. Also, could he not reconsider this question of letting the resettlement cases have priority because, as he put it, there are 50 to 100 cases per year from 1988 and beyond?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, regarding the first part of his question: whether we can increase the number of shops. I think it must be made very clear what shops are built for. They are built to cater for the needs of residents and, of course, they must be built in numbers that will make those shops viable. We cannot just build shops to cater for resettlement cases. As I mentioned in my answer to the first supplementary question, we already have shops in HDB estates which fall vacant all the time because people tender, they get the shops, and they find they cannot make a go of it, because there are too many shops in these areas. So to build more shops merely to cater for resettlement cases will not resolve the problem. In fact, it will make it worse for the resettlement cases. It is better for them to take the cash and do something else.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Why can we not let them have an option - either take the cash or give them the alternative of renting the shops, as was the case in the past? As I understand the position, is it not a fact that it is Government's duty to make sure that resettlement is made less painful and more humane?

     Mr Dhanabalan: We seem to be going round in circles. We cannot go back to the old system because we do not have shops.

     Mr Tang See Chim: Why not?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, I think the figures speak for themselves.

Column: 64



    Sir, we want to try and reduce as much as possible all the trauma of being dislocated, of being removed from businesses that they have been engaged in for a long long time. But we cannot also hold up development. We need these areas. And if we had not moved in the way that we did, Singapore would not be what it is today. It is because we want to try and reduce the hardship that we changed the policy and now allow a cash option which was not there before. In fact, many of these cases under the previous scheme would just have not got any shops, neither would they have got any cash. In order to alleviate their hardship, we offer this cash option. We have to work within the constraints of the numbers that we have and we just cannot squeeze more shops out of the numbers that we have to offer to all resettlement cases.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, can I ask the Minister whether he will try to understand the position of the affected shopkeeper by giving his impression as to how much or how long the $26,000 cash compensation will go to overcome or to resolve the shopkeeper's temporary predicament or maybe for the rest of this life? In other words, I am trying to suggest that the $26,000 cash compensation is just a mere paltry sum. It is depriving a shopkeeper of his livelihood thereafter.

     Mr Dhanabalan: It is not a paltry sum as compared to the zero that they got previously. We have to try and work out --

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: In the past, he had the alternative to rent a shop.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Not necessarily the case.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Yes, it was.

     Mr Dhanabalan: In the past, in the case of those shops which were in temporary premises, they did not have cash option but they had the option of tendering for a shop, and they paid 50% of the tender price of shops in particular areas. In other words, they paid 50% of the market rate, and it graduated up 10% per year over a period of five years. But not all were successful in getting shops. That also must be made clear. More than half or about half the shops in temporary premises did

Column: 65

not even bother to tender for shops, because they knew they could not survive, even paying 50% of the market rate. Many of them survived because they were paying very low rentals in shops or premises which were rent-controlled. And that is how they kept going. They could not have survived under a fair economic price situation even at 50% of the market rate. Now they get $26,000. Previously they would not even have got that.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is a real problem in resettlement cases, even the existing shopkeepers in HDB estates. In view of this, would the Minister be willing to set up a committee to study their plight with a view to pegging a reasonable rent for these shopkeepers?

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, there was a committee in fact which made a number of recommendations. Many of the recommendations of the committee have been accepted and implemented. To be fair to the committee, the committee recommended a cash option of $26,000 or a shop. In other words, in addition to the previous policy of just offering only a shop, the committee recommended a cash option. But when the Ministry studied the figures, it was just not possible to implement the recommendation and that is why we had to change the policy. I do not want to repeat what I have already said previously.

    So we have had a committee. The committee has looked at this whole subject thoroughly. It has made a number of recommendations. Most of the recommendations have been accepted.

    As to whether we can have a committee to settle what should be a fair rent, I think that is not possible. Fair rent is what the market is prepared to pay and the best way to decide that is by tender.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Sir, may I once again ask the Minister why he cannot consider an enhanced compensation for the structures and their improvements by shopkeepers? Under today's policy, farmers do get enhanced compensation for their structures compared to non-

Column: 66

farmers whose structures are compensated at residential rates. I believe that today the shopkeepers' structures are also compensated at the residential rates. So the proposed enhanced compensation is for the loss of livelihood which appears to be the case considering the effects of the new policy.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the compensation was fixed on the basis of an average advantage that a shopkeeper had by way of his paying 50% of the market rate. And this was calculated over a number of years and the figure arrived at was $26,000. As to whether we should give him more compensation, of course, Mr Speaker, Sir, it is easy to give away money. But somebody has got to pay for it at the end of the day. We think the figure that we have fixed is fair. I do not really see much reason for us to reopen this issue. If Members can make out a very clear case, I will look at it. But I have already looked at the figures and they seem fair. But if Members want to bring up new facts, I am open to look at their new facts.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, it is obvious that the Government has not solved this problem because there is still much dissatisfaction. I would like to ask the Minister whether he would be willing to reopen the case because the problem is still there. And if he does reopen the case, I hope he can give the Opposition a chance also to join in and look into the matter.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Sir, I think we should not be discussing about this subject as though it is something new. We have been resettling people for many many years, for more than 20 years. From time to time, we have revised resettlement policies to keep up with changes in circumstances and in situations. In fact, I would say that we are almost at the tail-end of our resettlement programme, because most of the squatter areas have been cleared. So it is not as if it is a new problem that we are confronted with and we need to come up with new policies. The revised policy was just a change to an old policy in order to cope with the new situation - the new situation being one where we just do not have enough shops to go round.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: We must solve the problem.

Column: 67



     Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, the Minister admitted that some shops have been tendered and retendered. Does he not realize that this is really caused by his admitting new entrants into the tender system? These people had no idea of the economics of the retail trade and just tendered high rentals which they could not afford to carry on later.

     Mr Dhanabalan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I disagree with that completely. The reason why these shops have failed and had to be tendered and retendered is that there are just too many shops and they cannot make a success of their business.

Column: 67

OLD LOW-RISE CITY FLATS
(Replacement programme)


    2. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board has formulated a programme to replace the old low-rise flats in the city with better quality flats and if he will elaborate on it; and what measures the HDB will take to alleviate hardship to families to be relocated.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The Housing and Development Board will demolish some of the rental blocks that have high vacancy rates. Land so freed will be used eventually for new developments. Depending on the location of each site, the redevelopment will include better quality flats. The new flats to be built on these sites will be the larger flat types. There will therefore be fewer of them compared with the numbers demolished. The redevelopment will inject new life into the old estates and improve the living environment and the mix of flat types there.

    The HDB provides removal allowances, priority to purchase flats and assistance by way of special financing schemes to the tenants affected, to enable them to buy flats.

    The HDB also tries to assist families who are to be relocated and who have special

Column: 68

problems. For example, for those elderly citizens who cannot afford to buy flats, HDB will try to rehouse them in rental flats either within the neighbourhood or in adjoining estates, wherever this is possible. These measures will minimize any hardship to families affected by relocation.

EXCESSIVE NOISE FROM ANG MO KIO MRT LINES
(Measures to remedy)


    The following question stood in the name of Mr S. Chandra Das-

    3. To ask the Minister for the Environment (a) if he is aware of complaints by residents of the high noise level along Avenue 8 Ang Mo Kio covering the Cheng San, Chong Boon and Teck Ghee constituencies, as a result of the running of the Mass Rapid Transit lines; (b) whether his Ministry has conducted any studies on the noise level before and after the MRT lines became operational; and (c) what possible remedies, if any, can be introduced to reduce the excessive noise level experienced by the residents.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng: Question 3, Sir.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Speaker, Sir, at the outset of the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) project in June 1983, my Ministry was aware that there will be noise from it. While noise cannot be totally prevented, measures can be taken to reduce it.

    My Ministry had recommended guidelines on noise control to the MRTC for their trains and mechanical ventilation equipment. These guidelines were formulated after a careful study of those adopted in Japan, the United Kingdom and the United States which were then modified to suit our local circumstances. MRTC had also taken every care in the design of their tracks and the specifications for their equipment to keep noise levels to a minimum. They have also with them the services of noise consultants to further advise them on these matters.

    The trains that are used comply with the noise standards specified in MRTC's tenders. In addition, continuously welded

Column: 69

rails are used to reduce noise from the tracks.

    At underground sections near high-rise buildings, tracks are laid on special floating slabs to cut down vibration and noise.

    At above-ground sections, the viaduct which supports the tracks is made of concrete with high mass and damping characteristics to minimize noise that may be induced by passing trains.

    These measures have been taken to ensure that the MRT is constructed with good noise control features from the start and should be adequate to reduce MRT noise to acceptable levels in most areas.

    Measurements made after the trains started operating show that some areas at Ang Mo Kio Avenue 8 are noisier as a result of the MRT.

    At these areas, additional noise reduction measures can still be taken. For example, the MRTC will be acquiring a rail-grinding machine to remove irregularities or corrugation on rails. Flanges of the rail wheels will be automatically lubricated to reduce squealing when the trains negotiate sharp bends. A wheel-lathe machine has also been procured which will be used to maintain the shape of the wheels at regular intervals so that they are smooth and therefore do not produce noise.

    My Ministry will continue to monitor the results of these noise reduction measures closely.

     Dr Ang Kok Peng (Buona Vista): Sir, I have two questions for the Minister. How many blocks of flats along Avenue 8 Ang Mo Kio are really having a higher dose of noise because of the MRT system? What other areas near the MRT system will experience a higher noise level in future when more MRT lines become operational?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Speaker, Sir, before I come to the Member's question on the number of blocks of flats along Ang Mo Kio Avenue 8, I would like to inform the House of the noise characteristics along Ang Mo Kio Avenue 8 before and after the running of the MRT trains.

Column: 70



    My Ministry has conducted a noise survey of the area and we have found that the ambient noise level measured in the HDB flats near the MRT prior to the trains running was about 70-75 dBA. With the trains now running, noise levels between 83 and 86 dBA have been measured when a train passes by.

    Sir, it must be noted that traffic noise from expressways measured at nearby flats average 75 dBA with peaks of 87 dBA. So you see, Sir, noise levels from MRT trains are therefore no worse than the present-day expressway traffic noise. Of course, it is understandable that people who live away from expressways but are now being subjected to MRT train noise will, initially, find the change annoying.

    As regards the number of blocks of flats affected by the noise, Sir, the number is 11. Based on the number of storeys and the proportion of units close enough to the tracks to be affected by the noise, an estimated 550 families living in those units are likely to be exposed to noise levels between 79 and 85 dBA along their corridors. Indoors, Sir, the noise level would be reduced by 5-10 dBA, meaning that the affected families are likely to be exposed to anything between 69 and 80 dBA.

    The other housing estates which have flats close to above-ground tracks are Yishun, flats in Bukit Merah area, Queenstown, Clementi, Bukit Batok, Bedok, Simei and Tampines. But as in Ang Mo Kio, I do not expect the noise levels in these areas to be more than traffic noise levels along expressways.

     Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, would the Minister explain what is the meaning of "dBA" so that Members like me can understand?

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Sir, I would suggest that the Member for Chua Chu Kang have a private session with me after this.

DENGUE HAEMORRHAGIC FEVER IN LORONG LEW LIAN
(Causes)


    4. Mr Goh Choon Kang asked the Minister for the Environment what were the causes of the recent outbreak of

Column: 71

dengue fever and dengue haemorrhagic fever in Lorong Lew Lian.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, Dengue Fever/Dengue Haemorrhagic Fever (DF/DHF) is a mosquito-borne disease which is endemic in Singapore. Disease transmission occurs throughout the year as the dengue virus and the Aedes mosquitoes carrying the virus are are both present in the country. Outbreaks can occur if there is an increase in the virulence of the dengue virus or an increase in the Aedes mosquitoes in a human population which is highly susceptible to the disease.

    There is a comprehensive island-wide Aedes mosquito prevention and control programme implemented by the Environment Ministry. The strategies are based on an integrated approach incorporating source reduction, health education and law enforcement. The overall Aedes population as measured by the Aedes House Index (which is the percentage of houses positive for Aedes mosquitoes) has been drastically reduced from more than 25% in 1969 to 1.1% in 1986.

    In spite of the reduction in Aedes population, outbreaks occur once in every few years. The notable outbreaks occurred in 1973 with 1,187 cases, 27 deaths; 1978 with 384 cases, 2 deaths; 1986 with 354 cases, one death and todate (this year) 302 cases, 2 deaths. In between these years, the average number of cases is 144 with one or two deaths a year.

    The Ministry of the Environment is concerned with the periodic outbreaks of DF/DHF and has demarcated 42 dengue "sensitive" areas for priority Aedes control. These areas are identified based on the distribution of past cases of DF/DHF, Aedes breeding habitats, human population density, housing types and development activities. They are closely monitored for any build-up of Aedes mosquito population.

    As there is no vaccine against DF/DHF, the only means to minimize periodic outbreaks is to ensure that the Aedes population is maintained at a very low level throughout the country. This could be achieved if the members of the public play a greater role in preventing Aedes

Column: 72

mosquito breeding both within and outside their premises. They should avoid keeping stagnant water and ensure that all water storage containers are tightly covered to prevent mosquitoes from laying eggs.

    On the outbreak at Lorong Lew Lian, routine surveys revealed that the Aedes House Index was about 2%. Aedes breeding was found in the uncompleted HDB blocks of flats at the proposed Serangoon South Estate, roof-top water tanks at Lorong Lew Lian, and ornamental containers in residential premises. As soon as a cluster of three cases was identified in Lorong Lew Lian on 28 October, epidemic vector control measures were immediately implemented. Up to 23 November 1987, a total of 7,043 premises have been inspected, 4,499 fogged with insecticides and 3,067 health education pamphlets distributed. The outbreak is being brought under control. As at 28 November, a total of 48 cases have been reported.

    The Ministry of the Environment will continue to educate the public on the prevention of Aedes mosquitoes breeding and to monitor the Aedes population and the disease situation closely.

    The Singapore Totalisator Board Bill seeks to establish a statutory body to regulate the conduct of betting by its agencies, and to give legislative authority for the property and funds of the Singapore Turf Club to be held on trust by the Club for the purposes of the Singapore Totalisator Board.

    Although the Singapore Turf Club is a private club registered under the Societies Act, gambling by members of the public is allowed both within and outside its premises. They do so by placing their bets with the Club. It is, therefore, the only private club to which the public have legitimate access to gambling.

    Horse racing in Singapore has been the sole preserve of the Singapore Turf Club since the last century. Through exemption under the gaming laws, the Club has the virtual monopoly to conduct betting on horse races. Strict enforcement of the gaming laws by the Police has helped the Club to maintain its monopolistic preserve all through these years. As a result, the Club has been able to generate a substantial amount of profits annually. Thus in 1986, the Club had an after-tax profit of approximately $33.67 million. As of 31 December 1986, its accumulated fund and reserves had reached well over $286 million.

    The Club's register shows that it now has about 580 ordinary members. Only this small group can share in the distribution of the vast amount of its accumulated assets and future profits should the Club be dissolved.

    Such a possibility is not in the public interest. The Club was not set up as a business proposition. It has accumulated its profits by virtue of the monopoly conferred by the Government and paid for by the public. It was never the Government's intention to provide a small number of the Club's members such monopoly benefits. Therefore, any funds so accumulated not through business acumen or risks taken, but merely by collecting bets from the ordinary members of the public, should not be left for the sole benefit of the members. The establishment of the Singapore Totalisator Board will seek to correct this anomaly.

    The purposes of this Bill are two-fold. Firstly, to improve on the Home Protection Insurance Scheme (HPIS) and, secondly, to safeguard against its possible abuse by CPF members at the expense of other members.

    Introduced in 1981, the HPIS insures CPF members who have taken loans to purchase HDB or HUDC flats. It protects such CPF members and their families from the risk of losing their homes in the event of the members' premature death or permanent incapacity.

    The Scheme has benefited many CPF members. At the end of October 1987, a total of 373,000 members were insured for a total sum of about $7.5 billion. So far, about 2,000 members or their families have claimed a total sum of $26 million under the Scheme.

    Although the HPIS has functioned smoothly, it can be further improved. Two proposed changes will enable the Board to:

    (a) provide insurance cover to non-CPF members who are joint-owners of the HDB or HUDC flat and who are responsible for servicing the bulk of the housing loans; and

    (b) provide insurance cover to the members as soon as practicable.

    The Board has also detected weaknesses in the present Scheme which could lead to abuse if left unchecked. These weaknesses are:

    (a) A few members who knew they were suffering from terminal illnesses could have arranged maximum loans for their flats and insured them under HPIS just before they passed away.

    (c) There have been instances of members who claimed HPIS on the grounds that they were permanently incapacitated from ever working again. They subsequently recovered and returned to work.

    The new subsection 25B(4) will allow a member to use his CPF contributions to pay for the premiums of his spouse if the spouse is a joint-owner insured under the Scheme.
